li.p: In this figure below, \triangle PQR has been rotated once around point A, and again around point B. Do you think we can get from the left triangle to the right triangle in a single rigid motion?
Perhaps you have come to the conclusion that it is a single rotation. How would one go about finding the rotation's center?

hint.p: If Q and Q'' is a single rotation, that would mean that they lie on the same circle. What would that mean about the distance from the center of the circle to Q and Q''?

li.p: Because points on a circle are all the same distance from the center of the circle (definition of radius), then if point O is the center of the circle, then \overline{OQ} = \overline{OQ''}.

hint.p: If \overline{OQ} = \overline{OQ''}, then O lies on the perpendicular bisector of QQ''.
